intro: Neogunnia drummondii, commonly known as the Drummond's ghostflower, is a rare and striking flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Onagraceae family, which includes willows and evening primroses, and is characterized by its delicate, white, star-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky, arid environments, often in crevices or on cliffs, where it thrives in full sun. Its narrow, grass-like leaves and ephemeral blooms make it a unique and visually arresting species. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species, highlighting the importance of conservation efforts.
